title: Rich Lister Nick Politis buys the dip as house price falls bite
text:
Car sales weren't the only segment being affected. People didn't feel as wealthy when they were constantly reading headlines about property price falls.

"It's everything from swimming pools to holidays and other things like that".

He said property prices had run up very fast over the past few years, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne and a fall-off had been inevitable. "It had to happen. Housing had to come off".

"Hopefully it's going to level out soon," he said on Tuesday.

Car sales slide

Mr Politis is chairman of the Sydney Roosters in the National Rugby League competition and was ranked No.82 on The Australian Financial Review's Rich List with an estimated wealth of $773 million. His wealth stems from his car dealer interests and an extensive property portfolio.

Mr Politis topped up his stake in AP Eagers in September and then accelerated his buying in small chunks throughout October, when the ASX200 had its worst month since the global financial crisis.

Advertisement

Private purchasers have been backing off at a significant rate in the new vehicle market, with sales down by 12 per cent in October compared with the same month a year ago.

Passenger car sales suffered a 23.6 per cent slide in October, in part because of the continued customer preference for sports utility vehicles, which now make up 44 per cent of all new vehicle sales. Sales to business owners and operators were down 4.1 per cent.

The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries released on November 5 a new set of VFACTs figures, which track new vehicle purchases.

They showed that 90,718 vehicles were sold by dealers in October, down 5.3 per cent on the same month a year ago. It was the seventh month in a row where new vehicle sales were lower than the same month last year.

AP Eagers has fared the best of the three main ASX-listed car dealership groups, with its shares about 18 per cent lower than they were at the start of August when the stock was trading at $8.58.

Automotive Holdings Group has fallen 33 per cent since then, while Autosports Group, which runs 23 dealerships that mainly sell prestige brands including BMW, Audi and Volvo, has dropped 23 per cent over the same period.

Autosports shares had an issue price of $2.40 in the November 2016 float, which raised $160 million but is languishing at $1.23.
description: Rich Lister Nick Politis is a big believer in counter-cyclical investing, topping up his investments during the October slide.
